Chief Complaint: cough and hypoxia Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: None History of Present Illness: Ms. is a with PMH of AS s/p TAVR (), AV block s/p PPM placement, CAD on cath in , HTN, HLD and remote breast adenocarcinoma s/p lumpectomy and adjuvant chemoradiation who presents with malaise. Patient was seen last week by her PCP and diagnosed with oral herpes simplex given lesions. She was started on Valtrex and oral steroids elixir on . On , she began experiencing congestion, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and cough. She was still feeling unwell two days later, prompting presentation to the ED. She denied fever, chills, chest pain, SOB, or sick contacts. In the ED, her initial vitals were T 98.3, HR 70, BP 97/41, RR 22, and O2 sat 87% on RA. She triggered for hypoxia and was placed on NC and given duonebs, with subsequent improvement in oxygen saturation. Exam notable for inability to speak in full sentences on nasal cannula. Lungs with rhonchi and wheezes diffusely. Labs were notable for leukocytosis to 13.6 with 83.7% neutrophils, Na 133, Cr 1.5, lactate 1.5. Flu A/B PCR negative. Blood cultures were sent. CXR demonstrated mildly patchy pneumonia in each lower lobe. The patient was given duonebs, 1L LR, azithromycin 500mg PO and ceftriaxone 1g IV. Vitals prior to transfer were T 98.3, HR 74, BP 110/30, RR 14, O2 sat 92% on RA. On arrival to the floor, patient confirms the above story, but does note that symptoms began about 1 week ago. She endorses sore throat, nonproductive cough, congestion, nausea and vomiting. She also reports diarrhea, at most about 4 times per day, with last episode the day prior to presentation. She denies blood in diarrhea. She denies fevers. She reports the cold sore on her lip has resolved and she thinks the lesions under her tongue have resolved as well. She finished the dexamethasone oral elixir but still had 2 days of Valtrex left. She feels her breathing is comfortable on nasal cannula, but denies having home oxygen. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: Per HPI, otherwise, 10-point review of systems was within normal limits. IMPRESSION: Well seated, normal functioning Evolut TAVR with normal gradient and no aortic regurgitation. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory Independent. Discharge Instructions: Dear Ms. , It was a privilege caring for you at . Please see below for more information on your hospitalization. WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL? You were not feeling well and had a cough WHAT WAS DONE WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL? We did an XRAY which showed an infection in your lungs (pneumonia), for this we stared antibiotics Your oxygen levels were low. We provided you with supplemental oxygen and monitored your levels. Your breathing improved and you were able to breathe comfortably on room air You developed an abnormal heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation. We started you on metoprolol to control your heart rates. Your heart rhythm went back to normal. We discussed the atrial fibrillation with your outpatient PCP and cardiologist and started you on apixaban to reduced your stroke risk. WHAT DO YOU NEED TO DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL? Take all of your medications as prescribed (listed below) Follow up with your doctors as listed below Seek medical attention if you have new or concerning symptoms.
